newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Iran's Rafsanjani says U.S., Iraq both to blame.
newsitem.headline: Iran's Rafsanjani says U.S., Iraq both to blame.

text.p: Iranian President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani said on Friday the United States had boosted tension in the Iraqi crisis to maintain a grip on the region, but also blamed Baghdad for giving them the chance.

"There are objectives pursued by the United States by creating such tension and that is to preserve their illegitimate presence in the Persian Gulf and Middle East," he told reporters after talks in South Africa with President Nelson Mandela.
"And of course Iraq has provided them with this pretext...by its invasion of Kuwait and its recent invasion of the Kurds (Kurdish lands)," he said through an interpreter.
"The victims of all these bad attitudes are the Iraqi people."
Rafsanjani did not comment on a U.N. report on Friday that 30,000 Kurdish refugees from northern Iraq had fled to three sites in Iran.

Mandela, who brushed aside U.S. displeasure to host Rafsanjani for a full state visit, also repeated criticism of Washington's actions which he made earlier this week, saying the United Nations was the body to sort out international problems.
"No country is entitled to assume the role of policeman," he said.
A U.S. armada of ships and assault planes closed in on Iraq on Friday, ready for a punishing bomb attack to end President Saddam Hussein's defiance of allied patrols of Iraqi air space.
